cards.title: Wimbledon 2015 / Djokovic lives to fight another day after Anderson scare
cards.rawTitle: Djokovic lives to fight another day after Anderson scare

item.title: Novak Djokovic lives to fight another day after Kevin Anderson scare
item.trailText: World No1 Novak Djokovic resumes his quest for a place in the quarter-finals on Tuesday having survived a near-death experience in a titanic struggle with the South African Kevin Anderson
item.standFirst:
• Djokovic went two sets down to South African
• World No1 levelled at 2-2 before play was abandoned due to bad light
item.body:
The world No1, Novak Djokovic, resumes his quest for a place in the quarter-finals on Tuesdayhaving survived a near-death experience in a titanic struggle with the South African Kevin Anderson.

That he lives to fight another day is an outcome that might not have occurred to him in the first two sets, both of which he lost in tie-breaks with the big hittingg, seemingly impregnable No14 seed. Anderson had his day of days, routinely firing down pinpoint serves of 130mph and sending Djokovic scurrying in the relative few rallies.

The agony went on for two hours, until Djokovic, two down and staring into the abyss, galvanised himself. Simultaneously Anderson seemed to lose an inkling of energy and a modicum of belief. By the time bad light stopped play at 9pm, Djokovic had secured two quick sets and had his rescue mission on track. But he will have seen enough to have no certainty about what happens when the two men settle the matter on Tuesday.

A pattern established itself early; Djokovic no match for Anderson’s ferocity; was forced to rely on instinct, agility and clever placement; grace under cannon fire. Anderson could just swing away. He hit more than 30 aces. Everything was going in.

Anderson started the tie-break the stronger, secured the mini break from the first exchange but Djokovic levelled, leaping improbably to his left to parry a backhand for a winner. With a deft lob that brushed the back of the line Djokovic went 2-1 up. Anderson broke back and the two men swapped blows until 6-6 when a hesitant Djokovic, long in his preparation, double faulted. Anderson launched another Scud to take the tie-break 8-6 and with it, after an hour, the set.

Anderson began the second in the same belligerent mood with deliveries Djokovic could only flail at. In the fourth game, attrition told and Anderson got the break to go 3-1 up. Djokovic, grimly focused, increased his intensity, diving, stretching, lunging. He pulled it back to make it 3-2, and energised by the chink of light, held his own serve to draw level at 3-3.

But still the Anderson artillery rained down. Djokovic went 4-1 up in the tie-break but Anderson kept pressuring. Soon it was 5-5. Then 6-6. After two mighty forehands and a deft drop volley it was 8-6, and Anderson two sets to the good.

The champion – desperate for a boost – got one at the start of the third set with a break of Anderson’s serve to go 3-0 up. Even now Anderson was hitting powerfully but less reliably. With another break for 5-1 the champion took the third set 6-1 in just 24 minutes.

Galvanised now by the sight of Anderson tiring and perhaps fallible, Djokovic also started the fourth set brightly. It took him three games to break serve. Suddenly Djokovic was imposing his game on the South African, driving him into corners and cutting off any responses at the net. At just after 8pm, in dwindling light, Djokovic whipped an angled forehand across the court, raised his arms. Finally, after three gruelling hours, he gained parity.

It was the last act of an intriguing As the two men sat down, play was halted. drama. The winner will meet Marin Cilic and it is to Anderson’s credit that Cilic still cannot know who that will be.

displayImages.caption: Play was suspended due to bad light with the score between Novak Djokovic and Kevin Anderson poised at two sets all, 6-7, 6-7, 6-1, 6-4. Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Novak Djokovic
displayImages.cleanCaption: Play was suspended due to bad light with the score between Novak Djokovic and Kevin Anderson poised at two sets all, 6-7, 6-7, 6-1, 6-4. Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

headerImage.caption: Play was suspended due to bad light with the score between Novak Djokovic and Kevin Anderson poised at two sets all, 6-7, 6-7, 6-1, 6-4. Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
headerImage.cleanCaption: Play was suspended due to bad light with the score between Novak Djokovic and Kevin Anderson poised at two sets all, 6-7, 6-7, 6-1, 6-4. Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

sublinks.title: News / Why Djokovic match was not moved to Centre Court
sublinks.rawTitle: Why Djokovic match was not moved to Centre Court

item.title: Wimbledon: Why Novak Djokovic match was not moved to Centre Court
item.trailText: Wimbledon claimed there was no need to move Novak Djokovic’s match to the Centre Court after fading light stopped his match with Kevin Anderson
item.standFirst:
• Serb fought back from two sets down before fading light stopped play
• Wimbledon: ‘No urgent need to finish match tonight’
item.body:
Wimbledon faced criticism from angry fans on Monday night after deciding against moving champion Novak Djokovic’s fourth-round cliff-hanger to finish on Centre Court.

Djokovic fell two sets behind against big-serving South African Kevin Anderson but had levelled the fourth-round match when fading light brought play to a halt on Court One.

Anderson had taken the first two sets on tie-breaks, setting up the possibility of a major upset, before a dogged Djokovic battled back to make the scoreline 6-7 (6-8), 6-7 (6-8), 6-1, 6-4, 0-0.

Tournament officials ruled out the prospect of moving the match to finish on Centre Court, where lighting under the roof allows matches to continue until an 11pm curfew, deciding instead it would resume at 1pm on Tuesday on Court One.

A statement on Twitter from Wimbledon said: “Regarding Djokovic/Anderson not being moved to Centre: Ideally, tournament scheduling aims to finish a match on the court it started. With no urgent need to finish the match tonight, both Djokovic and Anderson were happy to resume at 1pm on No.1 Court tomorrow.”

The match between Gilles Simon and Gaël Monfils was moved to complete on the main show court on Saturday night, but a tournament spokesperson said that was because of Sunday’s rest day, and the urgency to avoid the match being held over more than 24 hours to Monday.

However there were many tennis fans baffled by why Wimbledon did not look to complete the match between Djokovic and Anderson under lights.

Related: Novak Djokovic lives to fight another day after Kevin Anderson scare

Fan Nadine Erskine (@NadineErskine) wrote on Twitter: “Why stop play due 2 darkness when there’s CC w/ lights & roof? *sighs* #wimbledon Every1 else gets a day off! Not fair on Novak or Kevin!”

Emma Langan (@emzielangan) said: “It’s Wimbledon they should have flood lights on all the main courts! I’m so angry right now!”

Another surprised fan, @stephenkmonty, wrote: “Hey @Wimbledon, you have a roof with lights built in. Just letting you know for next time so you can finish the match. #Wimbledon”

Tracey Davies (@miss_traceydav) added: “Why was Djokovic match not moved to centre court under roof?!

“So @Wimbledon have a roof they can at under but decide to suspend play? Unbelievable, what is the point of the roof?!

“Roof had been closed once the whole of Wimbledon, what a waste! @Wimbledon what a crazy decision!”

displayImages.caption: Wimbledon's Centre Court could have been used to allow Novak Djokovic and Kevin Anderson finish their fourth round match. Photograph: Julian Finney/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Wimbledon-Centre-Court
displayImages.cleanCaption: Wimbledon's Centre Court could have been used to allow Novak Djokovic and Kevin Anderson finish their fourth round match. Photograph: Julian Finney/Getty Images

cards.title: Men's singles / Murray speaks up for Kyrgios and plays down his shoulder worries
cards.rawTitle: Murray speaks up for Kyrgios and plays down his shoulder worries

item.title: Andy Murray speaks up for Nick Kyrgios and plays down his shoulder worries
item.trailText: Nick Kyrgios found an ally in Andy Murray who spoke up for him and talked of the pressure on young players at Wimbledon
item.standFirst:
• British No1 explains how pressure of high expectations affects youngsters
• ‘I like Nick, he is quite different away from the court’
item.body:
Andy Murray is through to the Wimbledon quarter-finals for the eighth year in a row – and his 16th on the spin in a grand slam tournament – relieved and happy to get past the 6ft 11in Croat Ivo Karlovic in four sets on another day of drama at the All England Club.

While Nick Kyrgios was struggling with unspecified or “external bullshit” off-court problems, as he described it, and a mini-meltdown in losing to Richard Gasquet out on No2 Court, he kept his cool on Centre Court, winning 7-6, 6-4, 5-7, 6-4 in a little over three hours.

On Wednesday he plays Vasek Pospisil, who came from behind to beat James Ward on Saturday and who dropped the first two sets against Viktor Troicki before winning 4-6, 6-7, 6-4, 6-3, 6-3 in two hours and 39 minutes. The young Canadian, who has played three five-setters in a row, later lost in the doubles, partnering Jack Sock against Murray’s brother, Jamie, and John Peers.

Murray interrupted an answer during his post-match press conference to celebrate his brother’s evening victory, witnessed out on Court 12 by their mother, Judy.

Related: Nick Kyrgios faces hefty fine over protest at Wimbledon umpire’s warning

The world No3 spared a moment to sympathise with Kyrgios, whose post-match sulking has become an unfortunate sideshow here.

“I don’t think people appreciate how difficult it is to grow up under the spotlight, how difficult it is to have loads of people expecting you to be perfect from a young age,” he said. “I like Nick. I’ve spoken to him away from the court. He’s quite different to how he is on it.

“It’s not easy. He’ll find his way, for sure. He’ll hopefully have good people around him that can help him, people that have experienced being on the tour, guys like Lleyton Hewitt and Pat Rafter.”

Murray dampened concerns about a minor shoulder injury that inconvenienced him during his win over Andreas Seppi. “It feels better. I would have liked to have served a little bit bigger today. I’m still conscious of it, playing with quite a lot of taping on the shoulder. I played for three hours and it feels better than it did three, four days ago, which is positive.”

displayImages.caption: Andy Murray spoke up for Nick Kyrgios at his Wimbledon press conference talking of the pressures on young players. Photograph: BPI/Rex Shutterstock
displayImages.altText: Andy-Murray-Wimbledon

cards.title: Emma John / Karlovic’s hopes giantkilling quashed by Murray
cards.rawTitle: Karlovic’s hopes giantkilling quashed by Murray

item.title: Ivo Karlovic’s hopes of becoming a giantkiller swatted away by Andy Murray
item.trailText: The only people in any real danger from the giant Croat on Wimbledon’s Centre Court were the line judges - certainly not the British No1
item.standFirst: The only people in any real danger from the giant Croat on Wimbledon’s Centre Court were the line judges - certainly not the British No1
item.body:
We all know it’s not nice to judge someone on their physical appearance. Unfortunately for Ivo Karlovic, if he was hoping to be known for his charity work or his love of kittens, it went out the window as soon as he walked on to Centre Court. He loomed behind Andy Murray like the kind of Bond villain you just know is going to turn up later to try to garotte Roger Moore. Karlovic’s real nickname is Dr Ivo – y’know, like ‘Evil’. Even Barbara Broccoli couldn’t make this stuff up.

Related: Andy Murray into Wimbledon 2015 quarter-finals with defeat of Ivo Karlovic

As if to ram home the point, the ballboy assigned to stand next to him in his chair was one of the smallest, wispiest kids on their roster. One of the organisers clearly had a sense of humour. The editor of the Wimbledon programme might as well have gone the whole hog and annotated the map of Centre Court in a nice calligraphic hand with the legend: Here Be Giants.

Happily for Murray, literature has provided a lot of useful information about these fantastical creatures and how to deal with them. Karlovic may not have ridden on to court on a mammoth like the ones you find north of the wall in Westeros, but he can certainly wield his racket with the power of a club, something Murray soon discovered.

And then there are Tolkien’s stone giants, known to hurl rocks at each other for fun. Karlovic was always going to throw down some boulders from the baseline. You didn’t need to be a data analyst to know what kind of threat Karlovic posed: Jo-Wilfried Tsonga, whom the Croat had defeated in the third round, described his serves as cannonballs. The first arrived in the third point of the game, tearing down Murray’s right side and ricocheting off the side of his racket. Afterwards Karlovic blew on his hand.

It was all a bit John Wayne. When Karlovic’s serves made contact with the back netting, they did so with the sound of gunshot, and a couple had Murray pirouetting on the spot: ‘dance, British man, dance!’ It wasn’t just Murray in danger. Karlovic’s first ace hit the centre line, and, a nanosecond later, the lineswoman monitoring it. The ball bounced off her head, and she smiled gamely in response to the crowd’s loud “oof!” As the game wore on, registering several more near misses with line judges’ craniums, it became clear that whatever danger money they were getting for this gig, it wasn’t enough.

The match was a far more electrifying affair than either of Murray’s previous encounters. Karlovic, with his long legs, seemed to take only a couple of strides to reach the net, where he could then wait at leisure for Murray’s returns. The first set saw Murray scramble and lunge around like a man attempting the first human-powered flight.

Of all books it is probably the Bible that offers the best advice on how to dispatch a giant. Maybe Murray had consulted the first book of Samuel to be reminded how they can be killed by a much smaller man with a fearless spirit and a decent slingshot. Murray was in possession of both. He began to tease the tall guy mercilessly. He played cross-court shots with such immaculate timing that Karlovic was forced to watch as they whizzed back past him, using his own pace. Murray lured him into the net, then tormented the big man by dropping the ball around his ankles where he couldn’t reach it. As the ball hopped back and forth, Karlovic looked like Gulliver, irritatedly swatting at Lilliputians.

But these were as nothing to the lobs that Murray launched above Karlovic’s head again and again with a cheeky swagger. One, which landed in the far back left corner of the court, was so outrageously flirty it got a wolf whistle from the crowd. At the start of the second set, he played three in a row, Karlovic hopping, futilely, to reach them. By the time Murray won the third point, the crowd was laughing.

Related: Andy Murray v Ivo Karlovic: Wimbledon 2015 – as it happened | Simon Burnton

You had to start to feel sorry for his opponent, who spent much of the second set looking utterly bamboozled. If there’s one thing giants don’t like it’s people literally getting one over them. When a challenge went against him he had words with the umpire, who didn’t even need to bend in his chair to give him his ear. But Karlovic maintained his humour admirably. When the next line call went against Murray by the same margin, Karlovic raised his arms to the heavens in gratitude. And when Murray had an easy volley for a set point, Karlovic waved the same long limbs around in the forlorn hope of distracting him.

Murray, by contrast, found plenty to frustrate him in his own play. “Focus mate!” he yelled, and threatened to hurl his racket at the ground. He said afterwards that the game had been mentally, rather than physically, tiring. But it had brought out his best, and for that the spectators could be grateful.

displayImages.caption: Ivo Karlovic towers over Andy Murray as the pair shake hands before their fourth-round match at Wimbledon. Photograph: Ella Ling/BPI/Rex Shutterstock
displayImages.altText: Ivo-Karlovic-Andy-Murray-Wimbledon
displayImages.cleanCaption: Ivo Karlovic towers over Andy Murray as the pair shake hands before their fourth-round match at Wimbledon. Photograph: Ella Ling/BPI/Rex Shutterstock

cards.title: Women's singles / Wozniacki accuses Wimbledon of a bias to men on show courts
cards.rawTitle: Wozniacki accuses Wimbledon of a bias to men on show courts

item.title: Caroline Wozniacki accuses Wimbledon of a bias to men on show courts
item.trailText: Wimbledon don’t allow women to play on their main courts as much as they do the men according to Caroline Wozniacki
item.standFirst:
• ‘A lot of us women feel like we deserve to play on the big courts’
• Dane wants as many women’s matches as men’s on the main courts
item.body:
Caroline Wozniacki has sparked a Wimbledon sexism row by claiming women do not receive as many chances as men to feature on SW19’s show courts.

Wozniacki tumbled out of Wimbledon’s last-16 for the fifth time in her career on Monday, then hit out at organisers of the All England Club’s scheduling.

The Dane claimed Wimbledon’s tournament bosses should feature as many women’s as men’s matches on the top courts.

“I would love to play on a big court,” said Wozniacki, after her 6-4, 6-4 defeat to Spain’s Garbiñe Muguruza. I think that’s what it’s all about; you work hard and practice to play on the big courts. The women really haven’t gotten the opportunity here to play on the big courts. You only get one women’s match on Court One and Centre Court.

“Most of last week it was only one women’s match on Court Two as well. It’s definitely different, that’s all I can say. I think a lot of us women feel like we deserve to play on the big courts in front of a big crowd, as well.”

Wozniacki has never reached a Wimbledon quarter-final, despite this being her fifth appearance in the last 16. World No20 Muguruza eased past Wozniacki in straight sets, with the match taking place on Court Two.

displayImages.caption: Caroline Wozniacki believes more women's games should be played on the Wimbledon show courts. Photograph: Ian Walton/Getty Images

cards.title: Men's singles / Dimitrov parts with coach Rasheed after run of bad form
cards.rawTitle: Dimitrov parts with coach Rasheed after run of bad form

item.title: Grigor Dimitrov parts with coach Roger Rasheed after run of bad form
item.trailText: Grigor Dimitrov said he gave much thought to his form before announcing he was parting with coach Roger Rasheed
item.standFirst:
• Straight sets defeat to Richard Gasquet was big factor
• Dimitrov: ‘I have decided to end my working relationship with Roger’
item.body:
Grigor Dimitrov has responded to his lacklustre 2015 by parting ways with his coach Roger Rasheed. The world No11 bombed out of the first round of the French Open before slumping to a straight-sets defeat in Wimbledon’s third round to Richard Gasquet.

The 24-year-old has long been viewed as a potential grand slam champion, but has failed to meet that expectation, despite reaching the Wimbledon semi-finals last year.

While still licking his wounds from that premature Wimbledon exit, Dimitrov moved quickly to end the partnership with Rasheed that had started in 2013. “After much thought I have decided to end my working relationship with Roger,” Dimitrov posted on Twitter on Monday night.

“I want to thank him for all his hard work and support over the past couple of years. We had many accomplishments together and I wish him all the best going forward.”

While his girlfriend Maria Sharapova has sauntered quietly into the quarter-finals of Wimbledon’s women’s draw, the scratchy form that has dogged Dimitrov’s season has continued. He scooped the 2014 Aegon Championships title at Queen’s Club before dumping then-defending champion Andy Murray out of Wimbledon in the quarter-finals.

Many viewed that as the long-expected watershed moment for his career, crediting taskmaster Australian coach Rasheed for adding bite and work-rate to Bulgarian’s approach.

After reaching the fourth round of the Australian Open, though, Dimitrov’s form has tapered off in the following two grand slams.

When reacting to his Wimbledon defeat to Gasquet, Dimitrov admitted he can no longer consider himself a player of promise.

“I’m 24, I don’t consider myself that young any more,” he said. “Last year was an eye-opener for me, it showed me what I was capable of. I fell into a rhythm that I always wanted to, but I always knew it was very hard to sustain.

“Especially this year, I’ve had quite a few difficulties to cooperate with the situation that I’m not playing as good as last year. It comes down to a bit of mental strength, something that you really need to sort of look at it and maybe see what you can do different.”

displayImages.caption: Grigor Dimitrov has announced he is parting with his coach Roger Rasheed. Photograph: Jason O'Brien/Action Images

cards.title: Men's singles / Federer too hot for Bautista Agut to handle
cards.rawTitle: Federer too hot for Bautista Agut to handle

item.title: Wimbledon 2015: Roger Federer too hot for Roberto Bautista Agut to handle
item.trailText: The seven-times champion was in irresistible mood against the Spaniard, taking only 86 minutes to win in straight sets
item.standFirst:
• Seven-times champion wins 6-2, 6-2, 6-3 in 86 minutes
• Serve holds key for Federer as he reaches 13th quarter-final at SW19
item.body:
It was more of an evisceration than a match. But what an evisceration. In 86 minutes of surgical brilliance, Roger Federer gutted and numbed Roberto Bautista Agut until he had nothing left but his spirit. That helped the Spaniard save five match points but the jagged edge to the match came swiftly enough as Federer won through 6-2, 6-2, 6-3.

Forehand, backhand, serve, volley: all were scalpels in Federer’s hands. He won 92% of his first serve points. He hit 38 winners with just 12 unforced errors. And when he came to the net, as he did regularly, he won 30 of 40 points. It could have been 2001 again.

The win saw Federer through to the quarter-finals here for the 13th time, which puts him only one behind the record of Jimmy Connors. He has still not dropped his serve all tournament. No wonder he was happy afterwards. “I was hoping to get out of the blocks early and I was able to do that,” he said. “My last few matches have been dominated by big servers, but against Roberto I could work on my finesse and power.”

Next up for Federer is Gilles Simon, the No12 seed, who dispatched Tomas Berdych 6-3, 6-3, 6-2. Federer has won five of his seven matches against the Frenchman but most have been tight. As Federer admitted afterwards Simon is one of the best counter-punchers in the game. “I’m not going to look further than Gilles who has caused me difficulties in the past,” he conceded. “I played him tough in some of the majors – Australia and the French Open – and we played five sets both times there.”

That match will take place Wednesday afternoon, but the No2 seed will be able to savour this victory. Initially Bautista Agut seemed to be hanging with him, as the pair shared the opening four games of he match. Quickly, though, Federer was able to sprint away.

Two superb backhand volleys at the net helped him to his first break of serve. A peach of a forehand to his second. The foundations of Bautista Agut’s success at Wimbledon this year had been built on a high first serve percentage. After 19 minutes he had been broken twice and lost the first set.

The gulf in experience was enormous: Federer was looking for his 45th quarter-final grand slam appearance, Bautista Agut his first. The gap in class appeared just as great.

The second set started in much the same way as the first: with Federer on the attack. A punchy backhand volley put him 0-30 ahead and while the No20 seed was able to save a first break point, he was soon 2-0 down.

You could make a case for Bautista Agut having the edge in speed and he was doing the best to cover every blade of the court, but with Federer finding every line and angle it was not doing much good.

The Spaniard was able to stem the bleeding by holding his service game but shortly afterwards he slid to his right and injured his heel. The physiotherapist was called. Joints manipulated, he was able to carry on but as Federer powered another forehand past him and wrapped up the second set he might have had second thoughts.

Before the start of the third set the Spaniard’s ankle was taped up with a bandage. But the pain Federer inflicted continued regardless. In one game it took less than a minute for him to hold serve.

Federer has now – incredibly – not been broken for 105 service games, a run that extends all the way back to his first round match against Philipp Kohlschreiber in Halle. When asked about the startling run, he said to laughter: “The guys are returning terrible,” before admitting: “I don’t know but clearly having the extra week helped me be perfectly prepared for Wimbledon.

“Then again, Gilles is one of the best return players we have in the game so I would think I’ll be tested a lot in the next round. So that streak is maybe coming to an end.”

Batista Agut also kept fighting to the end but for all his stubborness and resistance Federer was way too good. Again.

displayImages.caption: Roger Federer won 92% of points on his first serve against Roberto Bautista Agut at Wimbledon. Photograph: Mike Frey/BPI/REX Shutterstock

cards.title: In pictures / Tom Jenkins' best images from day seven at Wimbledon
cards.rawTitle: Tom Jenkins' best images from day seven at Wimbledon

item.title: Wimbledon 2015: day seven
item.trailText: Guardian photographer Tom Jenkins is in SW19 to bring you his best images from a dramatic day
item.standFirst: Guardian photographer Tom Jenkins is in SW19 to bring you his best images from a dramatic day

displayImages.caption: Nick Kyrgios tosses his racket in the air during his defeat to France’s Richard Gasquet. During the match, Kyrgios received a code violation for swearing. He raged at ‘external bullshit’. He rowed with the umpire over whether he was taking too long to change his socks. He hurled his racket 10ft into the air.
displayImages.altText: Nick Kyrgios tosses his racket in the air during his defeat to France’s Richard Gasquet. During the match, Kyrgios got a code violation for swearing. He raged at ‘external bullshit’. He rowed with the umpire over whether he was taking too long to change his socks. He hurled his racket 10ft into the air.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Nick Kyrgios tosses his racket in the air during his defeat to France’s Richard Gasquet. During the match, Kyrgios received a code violation for swearing. He raged at ‘external bullshit’. He rowed with the umpire over whether he was taking too long to change his socks. He hurled his racket 10ft into the air.

displayImages.caption: Gasquet also lost it by smashing his racket into the ground. After the match, Gasquet spoke about Kyrgios’ antics: “He was a little bit angry, a little bit frustrated, I saw that. Sometimes it happens. He’s not the only one to do it. Even the best players in the world did it in the past.”
displayImages.altText: Richard Gasquet also lost it by smashing his racquet into the ground. After the match, Gasquet spoke about Kyrgios’ anitics: “He was a little bit angry, a little bit frustrated, I saw that. Sometimes it happens. He’s not the only one to do it. Even the best players in the world did it in the past.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Gasquet also lost it by smashing his racket into the ground. After the match, Gasquet spoke about Kyrgios’ antics: “He was a little bit angry, a little bit frustrated, I saw that. Sometimes it happens. He’s not the only one to do it. Even the best players in the world did it in the past.”

displayImages.caption: Kyrgios also hugged a ballboy. The Australian faces a heavy fine after apparently throwing a game in a sulk which provoked boos from the crowd. However, the player also won laughter when he broke off play to hug a ballboy on court.
displayImages.altText: Kyrgios also hugged a ballboy. The Australian faces a heavy fine after apparently throwing a game in a sulk which provoked boos from the crowd. However, the player also won laughter when he broke off play to hug a ballboy on court.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Kyrgios also hugged a ballboy. The Australian faces a heavy fine after apparently throwing a game in a sulk which provoked boos from the crowd. However, the player also won laughter when he broke off play to hug a ballboy on court.

displayImages.caption: Serena Williams took on her sister Venus on Centre Court. She won in straight sets which provoked this response from Venus: “I don’t think she would call herself the greatest player of all time because she respects everyone else and the accomplishments they’ve made. But the level she’s playing at is unprecedented. I can say that with confidence. So make what you will of it.”
displayImages.altText: Serena Williams took on her sister Venus on Centre Court. She won in straight sets which provoked this response from Venus: “I don’t think she would call herself the greatest player of all time because she respects everyone else and the accomplishments they’ve made. But the level she’s playing at is unprecedented. I can say that with confidence. So make what you will of it.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Serena Williams took on her sister Venus on Centre Court. She won in straight sets which provoked this response from Venus: “I don’t think she would call herself the greatest player of all time because she respects everyone else and the accomplishments they’ve made. But the level she’s playing at is unprecedented. I can say that with confidence. So make what you will of it.”

displayImages.caption: Venus Williams measures up a return to Serena during her defeat. Serena prasied her sister graciously afterwards: “Venus was playing really well so it was good to get it done in straight sets. She has a game to just knock anyone’s socks off.”
displayImages.altText: Venus Williams measures up a return to Serena during her defeat. Serena prasied her sister graciously afterwards: “Venus was playing really well so it was good to get it done in straight sets. She has a game to just knock anyone’s socks off.”
displayImages.cleanCaption: Venus Williams measures up a return to Serena during her defeat. Serena prasied her sister graciously afterwards: “Venus was playing really well so it was good to get it done in straight sets. She has a game to just knock anyone’s socks off.”

displayImages.caption: The sister come together at the end of the match. Serena now plays Victoria Azarenka of Belarus. “I’ve had a couple of tough matches with Victoria,” Serena said. “She’s due to win big”.
displayImages.altText: The sister come together at the end of the match. Serena now plays Victoria Azarenka of Belarus. “I’ve had a couple of tough matches with Victoria,” Serana said. “She’s due to win big".
displayImages.cleanCaption: The sister come together at the end of the match. Serena now plays Victoria Azarenka of Belarus. “I’ve had a couple of tough matches with Victoria,” Serena said. “She’s due to win big”.

displayImages.caption: Miguel Ángel Jiménez drifts off in the Royal Box during the Williams’ sisters match. Golfers Ian Poulter, Lee Westwood, Sam Torrance and Paul McGinley were also at Wimbledon unlike Rory McIlroy who was in crutches after rupturing ankle ligament playing football with friends in Bangor over the weekend.
displayImages.altText: Miguel Angel Jimenez drifts off in the Royal Box during the Williams’ sisters match. Golfers Ian Poulter, Lee Westwood, Sam Torrance and Paul McGinley were also at Wimbledon unlike Rory McIlroy who was in crutches after rupturing ankle ligament playing football with friends in Bangor over the weekend.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Miguel Ángel Jiménez drifts off in the Royal Box during the Williams’ sisters match. Golfers Ian Poulter, Lee Westwood, Sam Torrance and Paul McGinley were also at Wimbledon unlike Rory McIlroy who was in crutches after rupturing ankle ligament playing football with friends in Bangor over the weekend.

displayImages.caption: Next up on Centre Court was the fourth round match between Andy Murray and the 6ft 11in Ivo Karlovic of Croatia. Murray fashioned an artful, occasionally magnificent exhibition of defensive tennis to win 7-6, 6-4, 5-7, 6-4.
displayImages.altText: Next up on Centre Court was the fourth round match between Andy Murray and the 6ft 11in Ivo Karlovic of Croatia. Murray fashioned an artful, occasionally magnificent exhibition of defensive tennis to win 7-6, 6-4, 5-7, 6-4.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Next up on Centre Court was the fourth round match between Andy Murray and the 6ft 11in Ivo Karlovic of Croatia. Murray fashioned an artful, occasionally magnificent exhibition of defensive tennis to win 7-6, 6-4, 5-7, 6-4.

displayImages.caption: The Centre Court crowd appreciate Murray’s performance. “I came up with some good lobs, passing shots, able to use the angles a bit more, trying to keep him from coming to the net so much,” Murray said at the end of the match.
displayImages.altText: The Centre Court crowd appreciate Murray's performance. “I came up with some good lobs, passing shots, able to use the angles a bit more, trying to keep him from coming to the net so much,” Murray said courtside at the end of the match.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The Centre Court crowd appreciate Murray’s performance. “I came up with some good lobs, passing shots, able to use the angles a bit more, trying to keep him from coming to the net so much,” Murray said at the end of the match.

displayImages.caption: Murray celebrates after his victory. Murray has what should be a less physically demanding assignment in the quarter-finals against Vasek Pospisil, who has not taken a set off him in their three matches.
displayImages.altText: Murray celebrates after his victory. Murray has what should be a less physically demanding assignment in the quarter-finals against Vasek Pospisil, who has not taken a set off him in their three matches.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Murray celebrates after his victory. Murray has what should be a less physically demanding assignment in the quarter-finals against Vasek Pospisil, who has not taken a set off him in their three matches.

displayImages.caption: Novak Djokovic misses a return against Kevin Anderson. Djokovic went two sets down before fighting back.
displayImages.altText: Novak Djokovic misses a return against Kevin Anderson. Djokovic went two sets down before fighting back.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Novak Djokovic misses a return against Kevin Anderson. Djokovic went two sets down before fighting back.

displayImages.caption: Anderson had his day of days, routinely firing down pinpoint serves of 130 miles per hour and sending Djokovic scurrying in the relatively few rallies.
displayImages.altText: Kevin Anderson had his day of days, routinely firing down pinpoint serves of 130 miles per hour and sending Djokovic scurrying in the relatively few rallies.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Anderson had his day of days, routinely firing down pinpoint serves of 130 miles per hour and sending Djokovic scurrying in the relatively few rallies.

displayImages.caption: Djokovic struggled for two hours, until, two sets down and staring into the abyss, he galvanised himself. Simultaneously Anderson seemed to lose an inkling of energy and a modicum of belief. Djokovic lived to fight another day and they will resume for a one-set showdown after bad light suspended the match.
displayImages.altText: Djokovic struggled for two hours, until, two sets down and staring into the abyss, he galvanised himself. Simultaneously Anderson seemed to lose an inkling of energy and a modicum of belief. Djokovic lived to fight another day and they will resume for a one-set showdown after bad light suspended the match.

Simultaneously Anderson seemed to lose an inkling of energy and a modicum of belief. Djokovic lived to fight another day and they will resume for a one-set showdown after bad light suspended the match.
